Is it possible to trigger a rebuild on Jenkins as it failed the first time because of a global timeout?

JIRA is still down to non-committers for new issue creation, so I'm going to write down some text for those issues here while I'm thinking about it.

## Should users be given access to the main Metrics registry so they can add arbitrary new metrics?

Kafka Streams is largely a higher-level abstraction on top of producers and consumers, and it seems sensible to match the KafkaStreams interface to that of KafkaProducer and KafkaConsumer where possible. For producers and consumers, the metric registry is internal and metrics are only exposed as an unmodifiable map. This allows users to access client metric values for use in application health checks, etc., but doesn't allow them to register new metrics.

That approach seems reasonable if we assume that a user interested in defining custom metrics is already going to be using a separate metrics library. In such a case, users will likely find it easier to define metrics using whatever library they're familiar with rather than learning the API for Kafka's `Metrics` class. Is this a reasonable assumption?

If we want to expose the `Metrics` instance so that users can define arbitrary metrics, I'd argue that there's need for documentation updates. In particular, I find the notion of metric tags confusing. Tags can be defined in a `MetricConfig` when the `Metrics` instance is constructed, `StreamsMetricsImpl` is maintaining its own set of tags, and users can set tag overrides.

If a user were to get access to the `Metrics` instance, they would be missing the tags defined in `StreamsMetricsImpl`. I'm imagining that users would want their custom metrics to sit alongside the predefined metrics with the same tags, and users shouldn't be expected to manage those additional tags themselves.

So, why are we allowing users to define their own metrics via the `StreamsMetrics` interface in the first place? Is it that we'd like to be able to provide a built-in latency metric, but the definition depends on the details of the use case so there's no generic solution? That would be sufficient motivation for this special case of `addLatencySensor`. If we want to continue down that path and give users access to define a wider range of custom metrics, I'd prefer to extend the `StreamsMetrics` interface so that users can call methods on that object, automatically getting the tags appropriate for that instance rather than interacting with the raw `Metrics` instance.

If I use `consumer.poll(0)` it hangs forever in [this while loop](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/ConsumerNetworkClient.java#L259). If I use `consumer.committed(partition)` it hangs forever in [this other while loop](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/ConsumerNetworkClient.java#L162).

And the changes I've made in the branch mentioned above seem to be irrelevant. The updated unit test seems to fail with the current trunk too.

@jklukas JIRA was down due to some spam attack I think. You can try again.

As for the discussion above, here are my two cents (would love to hear from other people as well @mjsax @enothereska @miguno @ijuma @junrao ):
1. For the producer/consumer cases, all internal metrics are provided and abstracted from users, and they just need to read the documentation to poll whatever provided metrics that they are interested; and if they want to define more metrics, they are likely to be outside the clients themselves and they can use whatever methods they like, so `Metrics` do not need to be exposed to users.
2. For streams, things are a bit different: users define the computational logic, which becomes part of the "Streams Client" processing and may be of interests to be monitored by user themselves; think of a customized processor that sends an email to some address based on a condition, and users want to monitor the average rate of emails sent. Hence it is worth considering whether or not they should be able to access the `Metrics` instance to define their own along side the pre-defined metrics provided by the library.
3. Now, since the `Metrics` class was not previously designed for public usage, it is not designed to be very user-friendly for defining sensors, especially the semantics differences between name / scope / tags. `StreamsMetrics` tries to hide some of these semantics confusion from users, but it still expose tags and hence is not perfect in doing so. We need to think of a better approach so that: 1) user defined metrics will be "aligned" (i.e. with the same name prefix within a single application, with similar scope hierarchy definition, etc) with library provided metrics, 2) natural APIs to do so.

I do not have concrete ideas about 3) above on top of my head, comments are more than welcomed.

I think we can consider eventually add JSONPojo as some of the provided serdes in `o.a.k.common.serialization`, currently due to jar dependency I would suggest hold on that first until we may get a finer grained dependency graph in our client jar.

As for now, in the example code, there are a few of POJO types and I can see benefits of wrapping them in a factory instead of defining each one of them. What is your motivation of extending the `Serdes` factory for customized serdes, and using that as `Serdes.JSON()` in streams code, compared with creating an instance at the beginning, and reuse it whenever needed if it is only for a single particular POJO type?

Thats great, thank you!

I gave you "add page" privilege. Let me know if this didn't work.

On Fri, May 13, 2016 at 12:41 AM, bendrees notifications@github.com wrote:

> Thanks for the response Gwen. I drafted some content for a KIP, but lack
> privilege to create the Wiki page (don't see a "Create" button in the page
> header as the instructions on the KIP root page suggest I should). My
> Confluence username is ben.drees@gmail.com.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1348#issuecomment-218973219
@vahidhashemian It looks like you haven't mocked the offset commit response. This test uses `MockClient` which requires you to manually setup request expectations and the responses.

There's no technical reason that I can't create a `MyJsonSerde` instance and use that in my application, but it introduces an asymmetry between the built-in types and my custom type.

I find this style easier to read:

```
stream.to(Serdes.String(), Serdes.MyJsonType(), outputTopicName);
```

as compared to:

```
stream.to(Serdes.String(), myJsonTypeSerde, outputTopicName);
```

since both the key and value serdes are accessed from the factory.

Or is the intention of this factory that the user instantiates a single instance of, say, `Serde<String>` from `Serdes.String()` and use that single instance throughout the code? Why not have `Serdes` return singletons so that using `Serdes.String()` everywhere could be idiomatic? Are `Serde` subclasses expected to be threadsafe?

Created KIP-61:
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-61%3A+Add+a+log+retention+parameter+for+maximum+disk+space+usage+percentage
Today `Serdes.String()` gives you a new serde instance, but I'm also considering of using a cached instance at least for those primitive types where serdes do not need to be `configure`d.

Thanks! You can start a discussion thread on the KIP (as mentioned in the
process wiki) whenever you are ready.

Few things I'd like to see discussed in the KIP is:

1) When applying this policy, replicas may stop being identical (if a
replica happened to be on a disk with a busier partition, it may have less
data than what should have been an identical copy). This can lead to weird
scenarios following leader elections and consumers who try to read entire
partitions. Reasonable limitation? Or something we should be concerned
about and try to address?

2) How does this interact with log compaction?

3) The JIRA you referred to mentions a new configuration "disk.full.policy" I
thought it was an interesting idea. We can have options like "discard
oldest" (your pr, essentially), "reject new data", and "do nothing" (which
essentially disables the feature). What do you think?

Gwen

I've copied much of the discussion here into some breakout JIRA issues:
- [3715 - Higher granularity streams metrics](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3715)
- [3714 - Allow users greater access to register custom streams metrics](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3714)

sure I'll add those in
The reason we put the `Record.write(...)` in `Record` is to not leak Record layout internals to `Compressor`. Personally I still want to keep this in a single class file for future changes.

Hmm, I see. Maybe we need a different solution then and I will close the PR.

The problem with the current approach is that it has a mutual dependency between `Record` and `Compressor` (the former calls the latter, which then calls the former). This makes the code strongly coupled and hard to understand. Generally, the dependency graph between classes should be a DAG. I'll think some more how we can achieve that.
LGTM. Thanks for the last minute triage and fix.
@ijuma I agree it would for dependency better be a DAG. Looking forward to your next PR.
ping @enothereska @ijuma for reviews, this is suggested by @norwood when debugging an issue with Kafka Streams.
LGTM
Unit test passed locally. Merged to trunk.

Timestamps can be created in the following various cases to pass into window stores:
1. `context.timestamp()`, in which the timestamp are extracted from records, and we need to validate upon extraction.
2. `punctuate()` based on `PartitionGroup.timestamp()`, in which we need to guard against `NOT_KNOWN` which is -1.
3. `Windows.windowsFor(timestamp)`, in which we should only consider windows with start timestamp non-negative.

@hachikuji Thanks again for your help. I looked at `ConsumerCoordinatorTest` and it seems to me that `OffsetCommitResponse` does not deal with actual offset value, but rather with committing the offset and making sure the commit is successful. Is it possible that `OffsetFetchResponse` is what's needed here? I actually tried `OffsetFetchResponse` in the unit test [here](https://github.com/vahidhashemian/kafka/blob/KAFKA-3664-ALT2/clients/src/test/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/KafkaConsumerTest.java#L476) without an error; but, even if the answer to my question above is "yes", I'm thinking I'm not doing everything right there. The reason is I am making up the offset fetch result, while I actually want to check what the offset value of `partition1` is as a result of running the unit test and changing `consumer1`'s subscription.
Local unit test passed.

Should the client select the minimum supported API version (across all brokers) when talking to brokers in Kafka cluster or use broker-specific version for each request? The later may cause different results returned to the application for example for different topic/partition pairs in a mixed environment.
LGTM, thanks.
@ijuma 3) is handled correctly already before this PR, I just add a comment indicating other implementations of `Windows` to follow the same.

There are a lot of instances of this throughout the code base (KafkaClient, Producer, Consumer, etc). It seams to be a consistent style choice to be explicit but I don't know the history. 

I am not sure what we gain be removing it since its already there. If we do remove it we should probably remove all instances.

@vahidhashemian You may need both. You definitely need the OffsetCommitResponse to avoid retrying the commit forever, and you may need the `OffsetFetchResponse` as well since the current behavior may be to send an offset fetch after every successful commit.
Thanks for the explanation, LGTM.

@ijuma We also transitively depend on `annotations` via the `reflections` library in connect-runtime. That library is LGPL. I did a quick test and it looks like we can just remove the dependency -- I think its only used for static analysis bug finding and doesn't seem to trigger any errors when its filtered (I just built, removed `connect/runtime/build/dependant-libs/annotations-2.0.1.jar` and tested the `/connector-plugins` endpoint for Connect).

Could we update this patch to also remove that jar, validate the output of `releaseTarGzAll` to not include any of these, run system tests, then merge this?
Thanks @ijuma for the reviews . I will update the patch today and also create the jira for the issue you mentioned.

@ijuma @ewencp Currently we are using a fairly lenient resolution policy in Gradle. If you like we can open a jira to track strictly defining our dependencies (including transitive ones) so that we don't accidentally include any unknown dependencies as versions/dependencies change. This increases the fragility of the build and requires more explicit control/management, but its sounds like thats what we are looking for.
@ewencp, will do. @granthenke, feel free to file the JIRA. For a project like Kafka, it makes sense to be strict about dependencies.

I updated the PR with @ewencp's and @granthenke's suggestions. I checked that `jline`, `junit`, `netty` and `annotations` are excluded via `./gradlew *:dependencies` and looking at the files generated by `releaseTarGzAll`.

System tests started:

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/451/
